title: Nadal gains rankings boost from Djokovic as Medvedev passes Federer
text:
Nadal’s hopes of finishing 2019 as world No. 1 were handed a boost (Picture: Getty)

Rafael Nadal is guaranteed to return to world No. 1 next month after Novak Djokovic slipped up in Shanghai, with the Spaniard leading the world’s top-ranked male by 1,280 points with only two major events to go.

Despite not playing at the Shanghai Masters due to injury, Nadal cut the gap at the top of the ATP rankings to just 320 points after defending champion Djokovic was beaten by Stefanos Tsitsipas in the quarter-finals of the Masters 1000 event.

Djokovic will now lose his No. 1 spot on November 4 to Nadal regardless of how they both perform at the Paris Masters the week before, with the race for year-end No.1 in Nadal’s hands and likely to come down to the season-ending ATP Finals.

Djokovic slipped up in Shanghai (Picture: VCG via Getty Images)

Joining them in the eight-man field in London is Shanghai champion Daniil Medvedev, who is in a mini battle of his own with Roger Federer as he looks to end the season as the third-highest ranked player.

Medvedev’s 6-4 6-1 win over Alexander Zverev in what was his sixth consecutive final saw him rise above Federer to third in the Race To London, with less than 200 points between them.

Tsitsipas confirmed his spot in the ATP Finals with a run to the semi-finals, while fellow beaten semi-finalist Matteo Berrettini regained control of the eighth and final spot in the Race To London, with runner-up Zverev edging into seventh place.

The battle remains on for the final two spots of the WTA Finals in Shenzhen, with Elina Svitolina, Kiki Bertens and Belinda Bencic involved in a tussle in Moscow for the final two spots.

Despite losing in Shanghai qualifying, Dan Evans has become British No. 1 for the first time, with Kyle Edmund slipping outside the top-50 after failing to defend quarter-finals points at the Masters event.

Edmund extended his losing run to seven matches on Sunday, falling in qualifying in Antwerp – a tournament he won in 2018 – to Norbert Gombos, a result that will see his ranking slip even further next week.
